name: Bogomolov conjecture
rephrased: Points with very small 'height' (a measure of complexity) on certain subvarieties of abelian varieties are rare; only specific 'special' subvarieties, like those defined by rational equations or containing torsion points, can host infinitely many such points in a 'dense' way.
implication_form: If a subvariety of an abelian variety contains a Zariski-dense set of points with canonical height zero, then it must be a special (or torsion) subvariety.
solved_by: Unsolved in general, but proven in many special cases (e.g., by M. Raynaud, D. Cantor, G. Faltings, J. Harris, R. Lange, M. Hindry, J. Bost, J. Loir, etc.)
